children.subject: Maybe consider taking an extra semester for that senior year summer to do more research? Just a suggestion, I know extra sems are not optimal for some people.

history.content:
As a rising junior, I think it is a great time for you to get started with research. I don't see any reason to wait around until after you've taken upper-divs before trying to get research opportunities—just go discuss with the appropriate faculty, tell them about your interests and background, and see if they think you're a good match. If you get the impression that they think your background isn't sufficient, then you can ask them what they would recommend you take or brush up on—maybe it'll be an upper-div or maybe it'll be something else. It's possible some professors might think you'd need to have taken an upper-div, but I assume that for most professors it would likely be a case-by-case opinion formed by hearing your previous background, not a bureaucratic requirement that needs to be fulfilled. In many cases I would expect that your own interest and willingness to learn things that you don't know on your own are at least as important as your official course background.

As for grad school (assuming you mean PhD)—whether grad school is "worth" it is an entirely different question from whether you will able to. Whether it's worth it is quite subjective... it depends on your own ambitions and personality; two people with the same strengths and background can have entirely different opinions on whether it's worth it, and given that this is something whose utility would only become apparent a while after you have finished grad school, I think the amount of wisdom you can expect on the topic from current students is limited. If you're asking whether current background is somehow lacking, though—I don't think so; it doesn't sound to me like it's too early or too late to get involved in research and have a good shot at continuing in grad school.

As a rising junior, I think it is a great time for you to get started with research. I don't see any reason to wait around until after you've taken upper-divs before trying to get research opportunities—just go discuss with the appropriate faculty, tell them about your interests and background, and see if they think you're a good match. If you get the impression that they think your background isn't sufficient, then you can ask them what they would recommend you take or brush up on—maybe it'll be an upper-div or maybe it'll be something else. It's possible some professors might think you'd need to have taken an upper-div, but I assume that for most professors it would likely be a case-by-case opinion formed by hearing your previous background, not a bureaucratic requirement that needs to be fulfilled. In many cases I would expect that your own interest and willingness to learn things that you don't know on your own are at least as important as your official course background.

As for grad school (assuming you mean PhD) for EECS (I assume you mean ML as in your title?)—whether grad school is "worth" it is an entirely different question from whether you will able to. Whether it's worth it is quite subjective... it depends on your own ambitions and personality; two people with the same strengths and background can have entirely different opinions on whether it's worth it, and given that this is something whose utility would only become apparent a while after you have finished grad school, I think the amount of wisdom you can expect on the topic from current students is limited. If you're asking whether current background is somehow lacking, though—I don't think so; it doesn't sound to me like it's too early or too late to get involved in research and have a good shot at continuing in grad school.

children.subject: Another thing is that if you are really interested in PhD, you could apply for a Master's after Berkeley. That way, you can take some more ML classes and get some more research under your belt before applying for PhD.

history.content:
I'm trying to figure out if it is advantageous to go to grad school, given my current status as an EECS student (outlined below).

I'm a rising junior. I plan to take the 126/127/189 triad, however I plan to take these my senior year (126/127 in the fall and 189 in the spring). In the mean time, I am tackling the industry-related classes like 162, 168, 170, 186, 188.

I hear that research experience is a must to get into grad school. But I have yet to take my first upper div (170 & 186 this fall), and doing well in upper divs is essential to getting into a lab (so I hear). 

Given my current state, is it worth or even possible for me to go to grad school for EECS? I want to know if I should apply to a lab for helping my chances, but I am not sure if it's too late to do so.
history.subject: Going to Grad School for ML
